rewritten_query: What happens to the key and its associated data after 90 days of being deleted in Key Protect?
agent_response: Cryptoshredding is the process of permanently and securely deleting cryptographic keys and the data encrypted by those keys. In the context of IBM Key Protect, cryptoshredding occurs when a key is purged and its associated data is permanently shredded and removed from the service. This happens automatically after 90 days of a key being moved into the Destroyed state, or it can be initiated sooner by force deleting the key. However, force deletion on a key won't succeed if the key is protecting a registered IBM Cloud resource that's non-erasable due to a retention policy.

original_query: backups.
extracted_sentences: How can I delete a key?

To delete a key in Unified Key Orchestrator using the IBM Cloud console, you need to follow these steps:

1.
Log in to the Hyper Protect Crypto Services instance.
Click on Managed keys from the navigation to view all the available keys.
If the managed key that you want to delete is in Active state, click the Actions icon and choose Deactivated to deactivate the key first.
To destroy a Pre-active or Deactivated key, click the Actions icon and choose Destroyed.
After destroying the key, you can remove it from the vault by clicking the Actions icon and choosing Remove from vault.
Please note that when you delete a managed key, the key is detached from all target keystores, and all key materials and the metadata are destroyed permanently.
Also, if you want to delete a key ring, you might need to transfer keys to a different ring first.
For more information, you can refer to the document titled "Deleting managed keys with the IBM Cloud console".
what happen when the first user authorizes a key for deletion?

When the first user authorizes a key for deletion in Hyper Protect Crypto Services, it remains in the [Active state](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/hs-crypto?topic=hs-crypto-key-states) for seven days, during which all key operations are allowed on the key.
The second user with a Manager role can use the Key Protect GUI or API to delete the key at any point during those seven days, at which time the key will be moved to the Destroyed state.
It's important to note that because it is impossible to purge an active key, another user must delete the key before it can purged.

The key and its associated data will be inaccessible 90 days after being deleted, and will be automatically purged, or hard deleted, after 90 days, resulting in permanent removal from the Key Protect service.
What could happen if no action is taken by the second user and the 7-day period experies?
If no action is taken by the second user and the 7-day period expires, you will need to restart the dual authorization process in order to delete the key in Hyper Protect Crypto Services.
This is because the first user's authorization for deletion is only valid for a 7-day period.
After the period expires, another round of dual authorization is required to delete the key.
In case, the server expired, Could I remove the entry from the resource list?
Yes, if the server has expired, you can remove the entry from the resource list.
This can be done by deleting the server from the resource list, which will mark it for deletion and make it inaccessible for a limited amount of time.
However, the server will still be available for you within the resource reclamations for a certain period of time.
If you want to irrecoverably delete the instance, you can use the 'ibmcloud resource reclamation-delete RECLAMATION_ID' command.
Why could not I delete keys?
There could be several reasons why you cannot delete keys in Unified Key Orchestrator.
One possibility is that the key you want to delete is in Active state.
In this case, you need to deactivate the key first before you can delete it.
Another possibility is that the key is associated with resources and their data.
When you change the Active key to Deactivated state, the key is detached from all the target keystores, and not accessible to all associated resources and their data.
However, you can still reactivate the key so that it is accessible to the resources again.
If you are trying to delete a key ring, you might need to transfer keys to a different ring first, as a key ring cannot be deleted as long as it contains keys in any state.
If you have the service "Manager" role of both the key being transferred and the target key ring, you can transfer a key from one key ring to another using the UI or the API.

For more information, you can refer to the documents titled "Deleting managed keys with the IBM Cloud console", "Managing user access", and "Transferring a key to a different key ring with the UI" or "Transferring a key to a different key ring with the API".
If you are trying to delete a key in Hyper Protect Crypto Services, there is a 7-day waiting period that starts after you provide the first authorization to delete the key.
During this 7-day period, the key remains in the [Active state](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/hs-crypto?topic=hs-crypto-key-states) and all key operations are allowed on the key.
If no action is taken by the second user and the 7-day period expires, you must restart the dual authorization process to delete the key.
For more information, you can refer to the document titled "Authorize deletion for a key with the API".
If none of the above scenarios apply to your situation, it is possible that you do not have the necessary permissions to delete keys.
Make sure your roles and permissions are sufficient to perform the action.
For more information on roles, check out [Managing user access](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/key-protect?topic=key-protect-manage-access).

What could happen if I force a deletion on a key?
If you force a deletion on a key in IBM Key Protect, it will immediately deactivate the key material and the data encrypted by the key.
Any data that is encrypted by the key becomes inaccessible.
Thirty days after a key is forced deleted, the key can no longer be restored and the key material will be destroyed after 90 days.

However, force deletion on a key won't succeed if the key is protecting a registered IBM Cloud resource that's non-erasable due to a retention policy (a Write Once Read Many (WORM) policy set on the IBM Cloud resource).

You can verify whether a key is associated with a non-erasable resource by checking the 'preventKeyDeletion" field in the registration details for the key and then remove the retention policy on each registered IBM Cloud resource that is associated with the key before you can force delete the key.

rewritten_query: What is the Disaster Recovery procedure in this context?
agent_response:
The provided document discusses IBM Cloud's requirements for planning and recovering from disaster events. In the event of a regional disaster, the estimated recovery time for rebuilding the regional site and restoring the service at another location is 24 hours. Users must update the endpoints of applications and monitoring agents to point to the ingestion endpoint in the new location and restore the service instance's metadata from their backups. It's also important to note that historical data may be lost during a disaster, so it's recommended to backup the metrics regularly for auditing purposes.

In case of a disaster, users can continue working by implementing a manual failover to switch to another region while the region is being restored. To reduce the time to get up and running in a new location, users should backup their alerts, notifications, dashboards, and team definitions on a regular basis.

If applications and services are all co-located in the same region, users must wait for the region to be available again for business. However, if monitoring agents are deployed on systems that are not impacted by the regional failure, users can redirect metrics to other instances of monitoring in a different region.

Regarding Unified Key Orchestrator, when a user authorizes a key for deletion, it remains in the Active state for seven days, during which all key operations are allowed on the key. The second user with a Manager role can delete the key at any point during those seven days, at which time the key will be moved to the Destroyed state. The key and its associated data will be inaccessible 90 days after being deleted and will be automatically purged after 90 days, resulting in permanent removal from the Key Protect service.

If no action is taken by the second user and the 7-day period expires, another round of dual authorization is required to delete the key. If a server has expired, users can remove the entry from the resource list by deleting the server from the resource list, which will mark it for deletion and make it inaccessible for a limited amount of time. However, the server will still be available for reclamation for a certain period of time. If the user wants to irrecoverably delete the instance, they can use the 'ibmcloud resource reclamation-delete RECLAMATION\_ID' command.

original_query: What are the steps involved to delete the CIS instance?
rewritten_query: What are the steps involved to delete the CIS instance?
agent_response:
Based on the provided document, here are the steps to delete a CIS instance:

1. Delete the domain from the CIS instance first. You cannot delete the CIS instance after you add a domain.
2. To delete a CIS instance, you must first delete all global load balancers, pools, and health checks.
3. Then, delete the associated domain (zone). Go to the Overview page and click the trash can icon next to the domain name located in the Service Details section to start the deletion process.
4. If you are moving your domain to a different provider, be sure to migrate your DNS records and other configuration information to the new provider before activating the domain there. Activating the domain before migrating from CIS can cause your domain to changed to a Moved state.

Please note that deleting a CIS instance will result in the loss of all associated data and configurations. Be sure to backup any important information before proceeding with the deletion.

rewritten_query: Is it possible to add a custom domain?
agent_response:
Based on the provided document, you can add a custom domain on IBM Cloud by following these steps:

1. Go to Manage > Account, and select Cloud Foundry orgs.
2. Click the name of the org for which you're creating a custom domain.
3. Click the Domains tab to view a list of available domains.
4. Click Add a domain, enter your domain name, and select the region.
5. Confirm your updates, and click Add.

Please note that unless a custom domain is specified, IBM Cloud uses a default shared domain in the route to your app. You must register the custom domain on a public DNS server, and then configure the custom domain in IBM Cloud. After your custom domain is mapped to the system domain, requests for your custom domain are routed to your app in IBM Cloud.

rewritten_query: Could you explain what the transportation layer is?
agent_response: The Transport layer is a part of the networking stack that is responsible for end-to-end communication between applications running on different networked devices. It provides services such as connection-oriented communication, reliability, flow control, and multiplexing. The two main protocols used at this layer are the User Datagram Protocol (UDP) and the Transmission Control Protocol (TCP). UDP is a simple, lightweight protocol with minimum overhead, while TCP is a reliable but complex transport-layer protocol that adds connection-oriented features and reliability to IP services.

rewritten_query: Is privacy protected?
agent_response:
Based on the provided documents, IBM has several privacy protection measures in place. For instance, IBM's Privacy Statement outlines the company's general privacy practices and subject rights that apply to personal information. If a client or customer considers IBM's processing of personal information not to be compliant with applicable data protection laws, they can submit a complaint directly with IBM. IBM TRIRIGA Application Suite Manage Servers follow NIST guidelines and assess against NIST controls for data privacy. IBM Cloud Delivery Services does not use DLP monitoring and implements access controls on all databases restricted to privileged users only. IBM also provides DDoS protection for its environment.

In the context of adding keys to the Key Protect service, it is recommended to avoid entering personally identifiable information (PII) to protect the confidentiality of personal data. 

However, the documents do not provide specific information about the CIS instance deletion process or the transportation layer. For the first question, I would recommend referring to the CIS instance's specific documentation or contacting IBM's support. For the second question, the Transport layer is a part of the networking stack responsible for end-to-end communication between applications running on different networked devices, as explained in the provided document.

rewritten_query: {"class": "non-standalone", "reworded version": "What about data volume?"} The user's intent in the final utterance seems to be seeking further information related to the conversation, specifically about data volume. However, without the context of the conversation, it would be difficult to understand what aspect of data volume the user is interested in. Possible standalone questions could be "What is the recommended data volume?" or "How does data volume affect annotations?", but these may not align with the user's intent in this specific context.
agent_response: When you create a stand-alone block storage data volume, the volume bandwidth is assigned based on volume capacity, IOPS, and volume profile. The bandwidth for an unattached volume can be found in the API response for a GET /volume/{id} call. When you attach a secondary volume to a virtual server instance, the primary boot volume gets priority IOPS and bandwidth allocation to ensure reasonable boot times. Bandwidth for data volumes is allocated proportional to their maximum bandwidth, with the sum of all volume bandwidth equaling the overall "volumes" bandwidth. In the example provided, the remaining bandwidth allocated for data volumes on the instance is 1,607 Mbps (2000 Mbps less 393 Mbps for the boot volume).

rewritten_query: How should I use different types of pre-annotations and are there different tools for conversational and technical documents?
agent_response:
There are different kinds of pre-annotation methods available in IBM Watson Knowledge Studio, including Natural Language Understanding, Dictionaries, Machine learning model, and Rules-based model. You can run multiple pre-annotators at once, but you need to prepare the pre-annotation methods first. When multiple pre-annotators are used, the first annotation made to a span of text is saved for the results.

You can use one pre-annotator at a time or a combination of them based on your needs. The choice of pre-annotator depends on the type of documents you are working with. For conversational documents, you might want to use a pre-annotator that is designed for understanding natural language conversations. For technical documents, you might want to use a pre-annotator that is designed to understand technical language and concepts.

Pre-annotations can simplify the job of human annotators by covering the straightforward annotations and getting the annotating job started more quickly. However, the method used to pre-annotate documents does not restrict the ways that you can use the resulting model.

original_query: What are the steps to be taken to gather the relevant worker node data?
rewritten_query: What are the steps to be taken to gather the relevant worker node data?
agent_response:
To gather the relevant worker node data, follow these steps:

1. Check the conditions of your worker nodes and cluster before you gather data.
2. Check the CPU and memory level of your nodes. If any node is over 80% in either CPU or memory usage, consider provisioning more nodes or reducing your workload.
3. Gather information about your worker nodes by using the `kubectl top node` or `oc top node` command, depending on your environment.
4. Open a support ticket and include the worker node information you gathered.

Before opening the support ticket, it is recommended to review the information and follow any troubleshooting steps in Debugging worker nodes, Worker node states, and Troubleshooting worker nodes in Critical or NotReady state. In some cases, if all worker nodes in a cluster, or in a single zone, subnet, or VLAN are affected, you can open an initial support ticket without gathering data. However, you might later be asked to gather the relevant data.

Confidence: 95%

rewritten_query: What are the steps to update a classic worker node?
agent_response:
To update a classic worker node, you can use the `ibmcloud ks worker update` command. This command updates the worker node to the latest patch level, and if a major.minor version update is also available, it updates the worker node to the same major.minor version as the master.

Before updating, ensure that your worker nodes are up to two versions behind the master version (n-2). You can check the conditions of your worker nodes and cluster before you gather data by using the `ibmcloud ks workers` command.

If you need all your worker nodes to be up and running during the update, consider resizing your worker pool or adding stand-alone worker nodes to add more worker nodes. You can remove the additional worker nodes after the update is completed.

Confidence: 95%

rewritten_query: What are the steps to update a classic worker node, minor to major?
agent_response:
A major.minor update for a classic worker node moves up the Kubernetes version of the worker node to the same version as the master. This type of update often includes changes to the Kubernetes API or other behaviors that you must prepare your cluster for. Remember that your worker nodes can only be one version behind the master version (n-1). You can update the classic worker node to the same patch by using the `ibmcloud oc worker update` command.

Confidence: 95%

rewritten_query: You're referring to parts of a tag, possibly in the context of software versioning like 'major.minor' we discussed?
agent_response:
A tag consists of multiple parts:

1. X: represents the major version of an image.
2. Y: represents the minor version of an image.
3. Z: represents an incremental ID that determines the latest patched minor version.
4. <date>: represents the date that the image is built and available. The format is YYYYMMDD.
5. [hash]: represents the digest (manifest) of the container image. It is a unique SHA-256 hash.

rewritten_query: {"class": "non-standalone", "reworded version": "You're referring to NodeSync in relation to worker node updates?"} The user's final utterance "NodeSync" is not clear on its own, as it refers to a concept that was mentioned earlier in the conversation. Therefore, it is not a standalone utterance and requires context from the previous part of the conversation to understand its intent.
agent_response: NodeSync is a feature in IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service that helps keep worker nodes in sync with the cluster master. It automates the process of updating and maintaining the worker nodes, including applying security patches and updates to the operating system and Kubernetes version. NodeSync uses a full worker node image to reimage and reload worker nodes with the latest updates. To enable NodeSync, you can use the `ibmcloud ks worker update` command with the `--resync` option. Note that NodeSync is available only for clusters that use the IBM-managed control plane.

rewritten_query: What are the services of Virtual Network Functions?
agent_response: The services of Virtual Network Functions (VNFs) include virtualized network services such as routers, firewalls, and load balancers that were traditionally run on proprietary hardware. These services are packaged as virtual machines (VMs) on commodity hardware and can be easily configured, managed, and scaled on standard servers through the IBM Software-Defined Networking (SDN) controller. VNFs offer benefits like instantiation of virtual network services without new hardware, rapid service delivery with scalability, centralized policy control, and the use of the same routers, firewalls, load balancers, and VPNs as in physical hardware or other cloud providers.

original_query: Is it worth having a web chat widget on my website?
rewritten_query: Is it worth having a web chat widget on my website?
agent_response: Yes, it is worth having a web chat widget on your website. The web chat integration can help your customers start the conversation with common questions or tasks, display multimedia and interactive elements, and transfer customers to human agents for more help. It saves time and effort building and maintaining a custom user interface, and it is easy to deploy and customize to maintain consistency with your website style and branding. It also supports a wide range of desktop and mobile browsers.

rewritten_query: Could you guide me on how to add the web chat widget?
agent_response:
To add a web chat widget to your website, you need to embed a generated script element in your HTML source. Here are the steps:

1. On the Integrations page, find the Web chat tile and click Open.
2. In the Environment field, select the environment you want the web chat widget to connect to.
3. Click Embed tab to generate a code snippet based on the web chat configuration.
4. Copy the embed script to the clipboard by clicking the Copy icon.
5. Add this code snippet to the web page where you want the web chat to appear.

You can also customize the appearance and behavior of the web chat before it is rendered by editing the configuration object in the embed script. For more information, you can refer to the web chat developer documentation.

rewritten_query: Is web chat secure enough for passing sensitive data?
agent_response: The web chat integration supports security measures to protect sensitive data. When you enable security, you can authenticate users, encrypt sensitive data, and restrict access to your assistant. All messages sent between the web chat and the assistant are encrypted using Transport Layer Security (TLS). However, to ensure end-to-end encryption and secure authentication, you need to implement JSON Web Tokens (JWTs) in your web application server code. JWTs are digitally signed using a private encryption key that only you have, ensuring that each message originates from your website. The JWT payload can also be used to securely authenticate users and carry encrypted private data. For more information, refer to the documentation on [Enabling web chat security](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/watson-assistant?topic=watson-assistant-web-chat-security-enable).

Add user identity information
To add user identity information in the web chat integration, you can set the value of the `user_id` property.
If you do not pass an identifier for the user when the session begins, the web chat creates one for you in the form of a first-party cookie with a generated anonymous ID.
This cookie remains active for 45 days.
For more information, see [Adding user identity information](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/assistant-data?topic=assistant-data-deploy-web-chatdeploy-web-chat-userid).
If you don't want to use the built-in user identity handling, you can also generate a randomized universally unique ID to represent each anonymous user.
For more information about UUIDs, see [RFC 4122](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4122.html).
It is important to choose a non-human-identifiable ID that doesn't change throughout the customer lifecycle.
For example, don't use a person's email address as the user ID.
In fact, the user\_id syntax must meet the requirements for header fields as defined in [RFC 7230](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7230section-3.2).

rewritten_query: Could you explain how the web chat works?
agent_response: The web chat provides a conversational interface that you can add to your website or mobile app without writing any code. When a user clicks the launcher icon, the chat window opens, and the user can interact with an assistant to ask questions, perform tasks, or receive support. The appearance and behavior of the launcher icon, the home screen, and most other aspects of the web chat can be configured and customized to match your branding. The web chat also supports features like multimedia and interactive elements, contextual awareness, and transfer to human agents for more complex issues. It's designed to be easy to deploy, secure, and customizable, while also providing a consistent user experience across a wide range of desktop and mobile browsers.

original_query: How does version 6.15.0 differ from 6.14.0?
rewritten_query: How does version 6.15.0 differ from 6.14.0?
agent_response:
Version 6.15.0 of the IBM Cloud Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) command line interface (CLI) was released on 2023-07-11 and has some differences compared to version 6.14.0, which was released on 2023-06-23.

In version 6.15.0, two new commands were introduced:
- image-obsolete
- image-deprecate

These new commands support image lifecycle management.

Additionally, image lifecycle management was added to the image-create, image-update, and images commands in version 6.15.0.

On the other hand, version 6.14.0 did not have any new commands introduced. However, it did add support for more algorithms in the SSH key key-create command.

So, the main differences between version 6.15.0 and 6.14.0 are the introduction of new commands for image lifecycle management and the addition of support for more algorithms in the SSH key creation command.

rewritten_query: Could you provide more details about the new commands introduced in version 6.15.0?
agent_response:
In the IBM Cloud Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) command line interface (CLI) version 6.15.0, two new commands were introduced:

1. image-obsolete: This command allows users to mark an image as obsolete. Obsoleting an image helps in managing image lifecycle, indicating that the image is no longer recommended for use. Obsoleted images can still be used, but new resources should not be created from them.
2. image-deprecate: This command is used to deprecate an image. A deprecated image is similar to an obsolete image, but it will be removed after a certain period. This gives users time to transition to a different image before it is deleted.

These new commands, along with the added support for image lifecycle management in image-create, image-update, and images commands, provide better control and management over images in the VPC environment. Users can now mark images as obsolete or deprecated, ensuring that resources are created with up-to-date and recommended images.

rewritten_query: Could you explain how to use the new commands for image lifecycle management introduced in version 6.15.0?
agent_response:
To use the new `image-obsolete` and `image-deprecate` commands, you would need to follow the syntax and options provided in the VPC CLI reference page. Generally, the commands are used as follows:

1. `image-obsolete`: To mark an image as obsolete, use this command with the image CRN (IBM Cloud Resource Name) and the region where the image is located:

```
ibmcloud is image-obsolete <image_crn> --region <region>
```

Replace `<image_crn>` with your image's CRN and `<region>` with the region where the image is located.

2. `image-deprecate`: To deprecate an image, use this command with the image CRN and the region where the image is located:

```
ibmcloud is image-deprecate <image_crn> --region <region>
```

Replace `<image_crn>` with your image's CRN and `<region>` with the region where the image is located.

For detailed information on the commands, including options and examples, you can refer to the [VPC CLI reference page](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/vpc?topic=vpc-infrastructure-cli-plugin-vpc-reference).

Additionally, you can use the `--help` flag for each command to display a brief summary of the command usage and available options:

```
ibmcloud is image-obsolete --help
ibmcloud is image-deprecate --help
```

Remember that these commands require a proper authorization context, so make sure that you have the necessary permissions and are authenticated before attempting to use them.

rewritten_query: Is it possible to schedule a future status change to 'obsolete' in one month and to 'deprecated' in two months using these new commands?
agent_response:
Yes, the IBM Cloud VPC CLI provides scheduling functionality for the `image-obsolete` and `image-deprecate` commands. To schedule a status change to obsolete in a month and to deprecated in two months, you can use the `ibmcloud is image-update` command with the `deprecate-at` or `obsolete-at` option, specifying the desired date and time in the future for each status change.

For example, to schedule the image to become obsolete in a month, you can use:

```
ibmcloud is image-update <image_crn> --obsolete-at "YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss+hh:mm" --region <region>
```

Replace `<image_crn>` with your image's CRN, `<region>` with the region where the image is located, and "YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss+hh:mm" with the desired date and time in the future (in ISO 8601 format) for the image to become obsolete.

Similarly, to schedule the image to become deprecated in two months, you can use:

```
ibmcloud is image-update <image_crn> --deprecate-at "YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss+hh:mm" --region <region>
```

Replace `<image_crn>` with your image's CRN, `<region>` with the region where the image is located, and "YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss+hh:mm" with the desired date and time in the future (in ISO 8601 format) for the image to become deprecated.

To learn more about the `ibmcloud is image-update` command, you can refer to the [VPC CLI reference page](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/vpc?topic=vpc-infrastructure-cli-plugin-vpc-reference#infrastructure_cli_plugin_vpc_image_update).

Keep in mind that the scheduling functionality requires a proper authorization context, so ensure you have the necessary permissions and are authenticated before attempting to use the feature.
